div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. div.head: A Light Nourishment for General Use.
Allenburys' DIET
div.p: The "Allenburys" DIET is a complete milk and farinaceous Food, easy of assimilation, most agreeable to take, simply and quickly made. It is recommended in place of ordinary milk foods, gruel, etc., and whilst acceptable to all as a light nourishment, it is particularly helpful to Dyspeptics, Invalids and the Aged. In the sick-room it will be found invaluable and it is easily and quickly made, the addition of boiling water only being necessary.

The "Allenburys" DIET is readily digested by tose who are unable to take cow's milk and is particularly serviceable in convalescence. When taken as a light supper diet it will be found to promote tranquil and refreshing sleep. Although this DIET is a good for ADULTS and is entirely distinct fom the "Allenburys" Foods for Infants, yet it is also of great value as a restorative food for young children, especially during convalescence.

ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor and Manager - R. SNELLING. Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF. SATURDAY, APRIL 6, 1907. LORD MILNER AND THE NATION. "No one has so proper a right to give a lead in national organisation as Lord Milner" says the "Globe". At a time when the Empire was enduring the greatest crisis it had known for at least a hundred years, he was regularly communicating with his fellow Pro Consuls in every part of the Empire. The experience and conviction of many years, spent partly at the periphery, partly at the hub | of the Empire, appear in his remarkable son tribution to the "National Review," which should become the "locus classicus" for the creed he dolares. It is the natural development of the nation that it should produce ! Australia, in the little islands in great ocean well in the continental colonies Civis Britannicus sum," is as proud pasaport now as ever was the Roman boast. But this loyalty demands representation. The greater the divergence of the separate nations that compose the great nation, the greater the desire and need of some constitutional nucleus where the calls of wider external policy may be discussed. The expression of the nation's power is the Navy; and in the distribution of the Navy all parts of the Empire should have at least . consultative Voice Call this new thing in the Constitution Council or Conference, or what you will, it must be real, it must be dissociated from Downing street or any one spot in any island or continent, it must be genuinely representative, and it must meet frequently. Such is the kind of Lord Milner's message, expressing with a tine and, as it were, impersonal al truths to which only excess of prejudice or deficiency of patriotism can blind the public. THE RUMANIAN RIOTS. In spite of the change of Government at Bucharest, and the soothing official reports as to the lessening of the disturbances, which have been sent over Europe, it seems perfectly plain that the Rumanian riots are getting worse instead of better. An army of peasants, to the number of several thousands, is marching on Bucharest, and the Army has order to fire on them if they do not disperse before they reach the capital. The situation much resembles that at the commencement of Richard II. reign, when the peasants marched on London, their grief. ances apparently being very similar to those advanced by the Rumanian peasants. The present rising will no doubt and in much the same way, but meanwhile the change of Ministry must have tended to paralyse the Government. However, Mr. Stourdza, the new Liberal Premier, is an old Parliamentary hand, and three of his colleagues have also held office before. It is very unfortunate that public opinion should have necessitated * change of Ministry at this crisis, but that is one of the weaknesses of popular government, and the authorities will have to do the best they can without having really been able to grasp more than the salient facts of the situation. So threatening has the state of stairs become that the landowners have had to ask the Government for protection for themselves and property. The number of troops is hardly sufficient to quell the rioters, and there is also the danger that those peasants who have only recently been called to the Colours may get out of band and make common case with the drifters There is no doubt much distress in any districts among the peasantry, but in a rich country like Rumanis, with a population by no means overcrowded, much of that poverty is essed by the primitive methods of agriculture New Khedivial Hotel, CAIRO. emily Hotel, But Between beard Holland the Railway Station Lecture t bt. tant Sanitary am s ta up to date Opel the year round term for Government of sindh Army Ooster NEW MANAGEMENT. 11

div.head: LORD CROMER'S REPORT
FRENCH COMMENT
(Gazette's Special Service)
div.p: Paris, Saturday, "Les Debats" in its notice of Lord Cromer's Report comments on it in a friendly manner and remarks that the French will not forget that in their agreement with Great Britain it was declared that France would place no obstacle, in the way of England's action in Egypt by demanding a time limit to the continuance of the Occupation of that country or in any other way.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive drove back to Koubbeh Palace yesterday direct from Al Azhar where he attended midday prayer. His Highness is expected to come down to Alexandria on Monday evening next and will spend a few days at Montazah.

div.head: PORT SAID STRIKE
NO NEARER SETTLEMENT
(From our correspondent)
div.p: Port Said, Friday. Coaling operations yesterday were conducted chiefly by the ships own crews and in all such cases the work has been slow, but the strikers have not interfered in any way. The Orient Mail Steamer Ormuz was the only case where any trouble arose. A very clever ruse was exercised by the agents of this steamer. On the starboard side, (exposed to the shore) a gang of men from the ship were engaged shipping the bunkers, but on the opposite side & small gang of Arabs had been enlisted presumably under the promise of extra pay; doubt. less these men were only too willing to work inasmuch as their demands were being met as far as that steamer was concerned.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE DANCE
div.p: As was announced a few days since, the dance on Thursday at Ghezireh Palace Hotel was the last of a series which have been among the most chic and brilliant functions of the season. Even though many of the most popular visitors have already taken their departure there were a goodly numb or left to take part in this last festivity and though many preferred to spend their evening quietly sitting on the verandahs and in the gardens, the greater proportion kept the orchestra busy till clase on two o'clock. Lady Vivian was among the most energetic of dancers during the earlier part of the evening; she was wearing a very pretty frock of the semi-Empire persuasion in grey net with clusters of pink roses in her hair and corsage. Nearly all the prettiest dresses were of this popular semi. Empire form with the elevated waist line which is becoming graceful figures. That worn by Mrs. Park Lyle was quite lovely - soft muslin scattered all over with golden sequins, narrow rouleaux of satin, and gold embroideries confining the corsage and wei_hting the skirt. Mrs Rigden's frock of white chiffon bore handsome sorolls of rouleaux about the skirt, and the pink sash was caught up high between the shoulders. Miss Bennett, too, wore a lovely little frock of white net and and fine lace, the sleeves being of the modish kimono tasbion, and Miss Leverich's pretty frock of soft muslin also hung from an elevated waist line. Mrs. Rom was wearing a gorgeous gown of grey green satin,, with & very full Bursage confined by a handsome yoke of dull gold embroidery, and M18. Barrow looked wonderfully well in black velvet with a shaped berthe of lace embroidered with gold Mrs. Morgan was also in black with some fine lace about the bodice, and Miss Bullook, too, was in the same colour. It was Mme Heller I believe who was wearing the lovely frock of pale blue eloth souple trimmed with tiny ruchings and & waistband embroidered with rosebuds. Miss Tuck's pretty white chiffon frock had a deep pointed bibot Irish lace; and the same handsome dentelle was worn by Miss Makeller on a frock of yellow chiffon. Miss Mitchell, who came with Col. and Mrs. Gordon, was in cream satin, 1 a few crimson roses tucked into her corsage, and Miss Duffin was wearing a handsome frock of deep rose with a folsled corsage and sleeves inserted with lace and bands of satin à la japonaise. Mrs. Wilding bad on a frock of purple with pink roses in her hair and a large cluster of the same in her bodice: Miss Duke was in pink satin and Miss Mo was wearing a truck of much the same colour, Miss Er-kine Shaw's fresh and dainty frock way of white net trimmed wib pink satin ribbon and worn over pale pink. Miss Wanklyn, who with her sister aud Mrs. F. W Saunders have just arrived from Upper Egypt, was wearing a pretty soft frock of blue, while her younger sister was in white. The Misses York were also wearing blue lovely frocks of tissue with trails of chiffon flowers of the same colour, and Miss Fieldan toà was in blue, the transparent yoke of the corsage being embroidered with many roses and finished in front will be a large pink rose. The Misses Morcom were also present, as were Miss Miles, Miss Joseph and Miss Gearon, Mrs No. lan, Mrs Charlton, Mrs Peach, and many others who have done their share to make the season the success it has been.

div.head: SPORTS AT ALEXANDRIA
AMATEUR ATHLETIC CLUB
GRACED BY ROYALTY
div.p: preferable to the chilly winds that have prevailed of late. Patron : His Highness the Khedive. Vicepatrons : His Highness Prince Omar Pasha To ssoun, H.E Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, Cul. A. J. Chapman, 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers. President: The Right Hon Earl of Cromer. Vice-President : E. B. Gould, Esq, H.B.M. 's Consul General, 8. H Carver, Esq The members of the Committee were Messrs. P. W. Carver, F. C. Haselden, H. F. Dickson, W.T Smith, G. C. Stevenson, R. B. McLean, W. E. Peel, W. Thomas, W. M. Chevalier, A. C. Shepherd, R. L. Barnard, E. A. Giles. The judges were Messrs. PW. Carver and G C. Stevenson, Mr J. Clark Shaw acted as starter and Mr. J. P. Jones as referee. The handicappers were Messrs. J. Clark Shaw. S. R. P Carver, R. B. McLean and R. L Bai nard. The Clerk of the course was Mr. F. C. Haselden, the time-keeper Mr. R. B. MeLean, the Hon. Treasurer Mr. W. T. Smith and the Hon. Secretary Mr. W. M. Chevalier. Popular as the meetings of the Alexandria Amateur Athletic Club always are, that of yesterday, the 33rd annual meeting, proved more successful and popular than any of its predecessors, for an extra interest and grace was lent to the occasion by the presence of our Royal visitors, and magnificently did the club rise to the great occasion. The grounds of the A. S C. were gaily decorated with bunting, the stands were crowded with interested spectators, and thanks to the energy of the committee, everything went off without & hitch. The weather was not so propitious as it might have been, for a hot, dry khamsin wind was blowing, though, perhaps this was preferable to the chilly winds that have prevailed of late. The sports commenced at 1 30 p.m. and several of the events came off before the arrival of the Royal party at about a quarter to five. T.RH the Duchess of Connaught and Princess Patricia of Conna' ght accompanied by Lady Cromer and Miss Pelly, Lady in Waiting, arrived at Sidi Gaber from Cairo by special train at 4.30 p m., being met at the Station by H R.H. the Duke of Connaught, Mr. E.B. Gould, Major-General Sir John Maxwell, Major General Bullock, Lewa Watson Pasha, and Mr Myles Ponsonby. | Within a quarter of an hour of the arrival of the train the Royal party, preceded by an escort af Military Mounted Police, drove into the grounds of the Sporting Club to the strains of "God Save the King," played by the Don Boseo band, which performed throughout the afternoon. Their Royal Highnesses were received by the committee, the members of which were presented by Mr. E. B. Gould, and they then proceeded to the Khedivial stand specially decorated for the occasion, from where they could get a good view of the several events. Her Royal Highness the Duchess of Con. naught, the Princess Patricia and Lady Cramer were then presented with bouquets by the Misses Ryth Haselden, May Thomas and Phyllis Jones. Tea was partaken of by the Royal party in a special marquee which Mrs. Gould and Mrs. F Haselden had kindly provided. | T.R.H. took a great interest in the sports, the Duke coming down to the course to follow the tugs of war and subsequent events more closely. The attendance was very large, perhaps more numerous than at any previous meeting, and towards five o'clock the Club stands were packed. All Alexandria seemed to have turned out for the occasion. preferable to the chilly winds that have prevailed of late. Gould, Major-General Sir John Maxwell, Major-General Bullock, Lewa Watson Pasha, and Mr Myles Ponsonby. Within a quarter of an hour of the arrival of the train the Royal party, preceded by an ! escort af Military Mounted Police, drove into the grounds of the Sporting Club to the strains of "God Save the King," played by the Don Bosco band, which performed throughout the afternoon. Their Royal Highnesses were received by the committee, the members of which were presented by Mr. E. B. Gould, and they then proceeded to the Khedivial stand, specially decorated for the occasion, from where they could get a good view of the several events. |Her Royal Highness the Duchess of Con. naught, the Princess Patricia and Lady Cromer were then presented with bouquets by the Misses Ryth Haselden, May Thomas and Phyllis Jones. Tea was partaken of by the Royal party in a special marquee which Mrs. Gould and Mrs. F Haselden had kindly provided. | T.R.H. took a great interest in the sports, the Duke coming down to the course to follow the tugs of war and subsequent events more closely. The attendance was very large, perhaps more numerous than at any previous meeting, and towards five o'clock the Club stands were packed. All Alexandria seemed to have turned out for the occasion. Several ladies and gentlemen, who were at the sports had the honour of being presented to their Royal Highnesses. The prizes were most graciously distributed to the winners by the Duchess, Messrs. P. W. Carver and R. L. Barnard assisting. At the close of the distribution Mr E.B. Gould called for three cheers for the Duke and Duchess, which was most heartily responded to by the crowd. T.RH. then returned to the marquee, and at G.10 p.m., after shaking hands with the members of the Committee, and several other ladies and gentlemen standing on the course, drove off to Sidi Gaber Station. Great credit is dye to the members of the Committee, to whose careful arrangements and personal efforts much of the success which attended this 33rd meeting must be attributed. We wish particularly to mention Mr. Frank Haselden who e services were invaluable in getting the course in order. Werner's jump was 18 ft. 114 and with his allowance of 1 ft 3 in. won easily from J E. Isaloumas, whose longest jump this year was only 19 ft. 6, in 7 EVENT XV. 14 MILE HANDICAP).- 1st prize. 10 vols. R. L. Stevenson's Works. 2nd prize, Stoker's life of Sir Henry Irving. 3rd prize. Hogarth's Philip and Alexander of Macedon. (The above prizes were presented by the Ladies of Alexandria and Ramleh), Only 7 started out of 13 competitors. Ist A. N. Prosser 20yds, 2nd C.H. Glasspole

25yds. 3rd 8. H. Ryall scratch. 2yds between 1st and 2nd. Byds between 2nd and 3rd. Time 54 secs. EVENT XVI. FINAL NATIVE TUG OF WAR.--- 1st. prize, £3; 2nd prize £1.10/- Teams Competing. Tie I. Alexandria Guard Coy (Police) v. Alexandria Fire Brigade. After some exciting pulling this was won by the City Police EVENT N° XVII OBSTACLE RACE.- Open to all comers 1st prize £2 (presented by F.C. Haselden, Esq.) 2nd prize £1; 3rd prize 10/- 1st Corporal Macready, R D. Fusiliers ; 2nd Seaman Paul, H.M.S. Minerva ; 3rd Private Maling, R.D. Fusiliers. EVENT XVIII. div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Vendredi 6 Avril 1907.
div.p: Les télégrammes de Londres signalent ode nouvelle rédaction de 1/8 sur le taux de l'escompte libre à 4 6/8 pour cent. Comme on le voit, la situation monétaire tend à prendre une tournure de plus en plus rassurante, Ao Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais s'est maintenu à 85 7/8. L'Unifiée a regate 1/4 de livre à 101 1/2. La National Bank est restée id variée A %5 3/4, de même que l'Agri oole à 8 7/8, la Daïra à 15 1/2 et la Delta Light & 107,8. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptiens rétrogradé de 8 flancs à 725 et la Banque d'Athènes de 1 trane à 187. Malgré les meilleures indications d'Europe et d'Alexandrie tous ensemble, notre marché des valeurs est resté, ce matin, paralyse durant une bonne partie de la créance. Certes, la peur ne hante plus les esprits comme ces jours der niers ; on se montre plus rassuré, mais on n'en persiste pas moins dans l'indécision et dans la réserve. On a l'air de se demander si cette dépression presque ininterrompue est vraiment appelée à prendre fin, et l'on perd ainsi, malheureusement, de vae que tout nouveau recul de la route, amené par la latitude laissée au parti baissier, a pour effet de découvrir d'anciennes positions à la hausse et pour conséquence la vente forces de ces positions. Au demeurant, les liquidations réelles, qui touchent visiblement à leur terme, ont leur bon côté : elles achèvent d'assainir la place et préparent admirablement le terrain one reprise stable, que les rachats du découvert pourraient ai: 6m+ nt transformer on une bonne bauase. D'ailleurs, is clôture, dans son ensemble, a été relativement ferme. Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Notional s'est raffermie & 25 18/16. L'Agricole a mollia 8 3/4. La Cassa di Soonto s'est alourdie À 209. Le Crédit Foncier a avancé . 730 et son obligation & lots ancienne à 340. La Nile Land a progressé à 30 1/2. L'Immobilière a rétrograde 376. Ba bonde tendance, l'Enterprise and Development a gagné environ 11/16 à 11 3/4 7/8. L'Allotement a fléchi à 2 15/16-3 ; as part clôturé à 102. Les Jouissances Baux de Caisse ont bénéficié de 4 trados à 255. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont été tenues à 10 8/8 et leur part. 197. L'Epargne Immobilière est restée à 2 7/8; 88 part a été ramenée à 110. Dans le groupe des valeurs bôtelières, les Nongovicb oot reculé à 26 1/2, les Egyptian à 10 et les Upper Egypt à 4. Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est tassée # 3 5/16. Las Estates ont progressé & 17/8. Les Abdy sont remontés à 1 1/16. Les New Egyptian ont fléchi « 20 sh. 9 21, les Salt and Soda à 19 sh. et les Khedivial Mail 27 sh. 6. Les Constructions se sont raffermies * £015/16. Nous détachons d'un de nos correspondances de Londres, en date du 28 Mars, l'intéressant passage ci-après : "Il est à noter que les valeurs égyptiennes n'ont pas souffert seulement da chef de la crise monétaire générale, aggravée par la débâcle da maroobé de New York. Ce qui les a atteintes tout spécialement par dessus le marboré, c'est le tapage fait par les journaux au sujet des appréhensions cat sées par la prétendue organisation du parti nationaliste en Byte. B lisant certains articles alarmants publiés à Londres aussi bien qos Paris, & Berlin, à Bruxelles et ailleurs, on pouvait croire aisément, en effet, qu'il y avait danger de graves perturbations sur les bords du Nil, ce qui n'était pas fait pour inspirer confiance aux capitaux européens. Heureusement, le rapport de Lord Cromer vient à point pour dissiper les craintes biométriques en montrant que | l'ordre de choses solide établi par l'un patior

n'a jamais rien risqué et ne court paiement le danger d'être compromis à l'avenir." La groupe qui voulait saboter en bloc le terrains de la Société des Excelsior Hôtels LE. 46 1/4 le mètre n'a pu donner suite à son projet. Le terme de l'option « définitivement expiré le 9 Avril courant, et les 750 livres d'ar hos restent acquises i la Société. Dans la séance qu'il a tengo bier, le conseil d'administration des Bzo Elsior Hôtels aurait paraît-il, décidé de faire bâtir le terrains et de les vendre par parcelles. Os espère, par ce moyen, obtenir un résultat plus rémunérateur que par une vente globale. Les actionnaires de l'Egyptian Delta Land and investment Co. sont informés que le deraiør courrier postal par lequel ils peuvent se voyer leur procuration Londres pour l'anom blée générale extraordinaire du 16 Avril 200 coat, est celui de dimanche prochain. Das formules de préparations, singi que des copies des résolutions qui seront soumises à l'assemblée, se trouvent à la disposition des ac CID DAINOS à la National Bank, als Bank of Egypt, a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Crédit Lyonnais et & la Banque Impériale Ottomane, au Caire et à Alexandrie. . Le quorum n'ayant pas été atteint à l'assemb:ée générale extraordinaire de la Société des Ciments d'Egypte, réunie à Bruxelles le 30 Mars dernier, une nouvelle assemblée ne tiendra le 20 Avril courant. A l'ordre du jour : réduo. tion du capital social de moitié, reconstitution du capital social par une émission de 15-000 actions de 50 francs ; nomination d'administrateurs et commissaires. Carnet de l'actionnaire. Les actionnaires de l'Égypte and Levant Steam Bip Co. sont informés que le premier dividende déclaré au taux de 5%. depois la date des appels pour la période finissant le 31 janvier 1907 est payable à partir du 8 avril courant à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bauka Alexandrie et au Caire.

div.head: ANGLO EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENT CO.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the above Company was held at 4 p.m. on Saturday March 30th. at the Company's offices in Cairo. HE. Hassan Pasha Assem, the Chairman of the Board, presiding. The notice convening the meeting having been read, the Chairman said : "In presenting their first annual report pour Board has to regret the absence from the meeting to day of the Chairman Sir William Willcocks. As you are doubtless Aware he was attacked by fever whilst travelling in Uganda and has been unable to return to Egypt for this meeting as he had hoped to do. I am glad to say that the latest news states he is improving rapidly, Since the formation of the Company two properties have been acquired in Lower Egypt at Bastara and at Manchieh El Ibrahimieh both in the province of Behera. Bastara Property - 1505f7k 168 were acquired in all at a cost of LB. 103,254,629 about L.E. 68 per feddan, A capital expenditure of L.E. 4.288 183 has been made on the property comprised as follows: New Canals, drains and roads LE. 3,079.184 Managers house, cattle sta bles, ezbase. Installation of a pump and flour mill. Destruction of old banks, etc., and Kassabia work. 323.999 735 150 L.E. 4.288.183 giving a total cost per feddan of about LE 71}. The system of irrigation and communications made by the former owner was adopted and developed. The property to day is divided by these works into suitable and well defined blocks for sale anil minor canals and drainage channels ensure a rapid amelioration of the land and admit sales of plots of any size suitable to large or small purchasers, TE The sales up to December 31st amounted to 85.15.14 for LE. 10892.789. As our report states, this is equivalent to a price per feddan over LE. 120. The sale price shews a profit of 25% on the initial outlay. The sum of LE. 867,834 in the balance sheet shews the proht on the amount of capital actually encashed; credit for the remainder of the profit will be taken as the annual instalments are paid: The ezbas built on the properties last year are now full, the rents have largely increased and demands to buy plots at advantageous prices are continually being made. Permission to erect a pump to lift drainage water into the government drain has been granted by the Irrigation department, and a pump and corn mill is being installed. The drainage in 1906 was all by free flow, but the possession of a pump ensures continual drainage if at any time the government drain should be unusually high. Manchiet El Ibrahimieh Property 1179 f. 13 k 08. bought for LE. 66055 470-, sinee purchase a completely new drainage system has been installed at a cost of L.E. 1429.877. Three horse tambours and one steam tambour have been installed to lift drainage when necessary but the rotations on the Government drains have given free flow to drainage water almost continua ly during flood time. Two new ezbase have been built for LE 576, and L.E.800 approximately has been spent in kassees work and levelling old banks. The Property to-day represents a total capital value of LE 68361.847 equal to a cost per feddan of LE 58 approximately. The Irrigation Department have completely remodelled the Telmeh Canal which traverses the property, and a greatly improved water supply will result. No land has been sold

yet, except a small strip to enable a neighbouring landowner to have communication with the public drain The results here also have largely increased this year and it is intended to bring under rice cultivation an area that had been previously neglected. The Board is prepared to increase their agricultural holdings in Egypt, but with the greatly increased price even of undeveloped land it is very difficult to acquire properties that assures safe and immediate profit. Although the statutes would enable the Company to deal in building lands none have been acquired, as in Cairo and Alexandria, as well as the smaller towns and villages of Egypt the speculation in building land has developed in the last year to such a degree that the directors have not thought it advisable to buy building land. In accordance with the decision of the extraordinary general meeting held last March, your Board decided to extend the operations of the Company to Cyprus, and the Chairman of the Board was empowered to treat with the Government of the island for an Agricultural Bank concession and to acquire properties in the island on behalf of the Company. The broad lines of the bank concession are detailed in the annual report and the Company has had the good fortune to acquire the services of Mr. B. G mirayan to undertake the management of the bank. This gentleman has been an official in various government departments for a great number of years and his experience and thorough knowledge of the island will be of the greatest service in developing this portion of our work. Four long loans L.E. 1755 have been made at 8% ; there are 200 long loans at 9%. The short loans have been made to groups of villagers each of whom is responsible for his own loan and that of his associates, careful enquiry is made of the solvability of these men before the loan is ratified. The absence of a land tax in specie makes it impossible for the bank to calculate the amount that can be advanced on a property according to the fixed government tax as has been done on broad lines in this country : in Cyprus the securities offered are carefully examined in detail with the aid of the govern ment officials and a general examination of the registered sales of land is being initiated which will form an accurate and valuable guide to valuations. Before leaving the subject of the agricultural bank I feel justified in stating that the government of Cyprus believe that an institution such as we are building up will largely benefit the island and we owe a debt of gratitude to the officials to whose aid and co-operation is due in a large measure its success. The last return from Cyprus gives the total amount out on loan up to £23,612. We now come to our land investments in Cyprus. When it was decided to acquire interests in the island your chairman undertook to study the matter, and the purchases made were negotiated and concluded by him, and furthermore voluntarily undertake the management in Cyprus during 1906 which he only relinquished shortly before Christmas. I will first turn to our Famagusta property. The development of this town was taken up by the Government within recent years. A harbour with a deep-water quay has been constructed where ships can be alongside in all weather and a railway has been made from Famagusta to Nicosia, the Capital town of Cyprus, and thence on to Morphon. Both these works were only concluded in 1905 and their presence cannot but largely increase in the near future the importance of the town and the amount of business transacted there. We have acquired an area of about 19 feddans adjoining the quay and railway , roads have been made on these lands and with a view to development of the property for building purposes. We are building a small cafe and a hotel, 9 stores, 8 shops and a Khan and boundary wall. These will cost property for building purposes. We are building a small cafe and a hotel, 9 stores, 8 shops and a Kban and boundary wall. These will cost approximately L.E. 5270 It is hoped to rent these on satisfactory terms and that their presence will aid in developing the reminder of the lands. The area of 10,000 square yards approximately, of which mention is made in the report, will be utilised in great part for the erection of stores from which the Company should ultimately obtain considerable revenue. The rest of the Famagusta land lies chiefly between the quay and the main railway station, a distance of between one and two kilometres. The Company has constructed two dwelling houses for the use of the Company's representative in the Island and the manager of the Agricultural Bank. A building for the offices of the Company and of the bank, has been corrected and is now in use. A building is in the process of erection which will be in part occupied when ready by the Imperial Ottoman Bank and in part by the telegraph offices. On the other side the government is erecting new offices, lawton arts etc., for the district, of which l'amagusta is the chief town. A building in fact corresponding to the Mudirich offices in this country, The presence of these governments and business, buildings adjoining our lands must, materially enhance their value in the near fu. ture. The cost of the buildings will be about L.E.3200. We are also creating a dairy at Fau agusta. We shall experiment on lands near l'amagusta toe in various fodder crops. will supply green food to milking cows during the summer and if, as we hope to be, we are successful in this, a large dury and cat:le rearing farm will be started. The dairy pro duets will find a ready sale in the island ani! for export: and we all know, the good prices cattle command in Egypt. A large part of our Famagusta lands were formerly built on or laid out in gardens the old wells are being opened up and new ones made where needed, and fruit and vegetable gardens are being planted The orange and pomegranate gardens in the neighbourhood are famous for the quality of their

yet, except a small strip to enable a neighbouring landowner to have communication with the public drain The results here also have largely increased this year and it is intended to bring under rice cultivation an area that had been previously neglected. A large part of our Famagusta lands were formerly built on or laid out in gardens the old wells are being opened up and new ones made where needed, and fruit and vegetable gardens are being planted The orange and pomegranate gardens in the neighbourhood are famous for the quality of their -frait and their productiviness: the water is h raised from wells by sakkies and windmills. In the district between Famagusta and Nicosia we have bought 3 properties of an approximate area of 1070 ferndale. Accurate surveys are now being made of our lands. Excluding farm buildings threshing floors veete, practically the whole of this area is under cultivation. Part of the lands are leased 28 to peasants and part onder direct cultivation, the whole area has been manured with chemical manure. The approximate price of this land rel per feddan was L.E. 11. We have also acquired in this district from ot the Government an area of 3,564) feddans od which have cost us about LE 23 per feddan. ve These lands consist of reservoir sites, lands y lying below the reservoirs which were formerly marshes but have been drained by the government, and are now coming under cultivation and other uncultivated lands. We were unable to take up the development of these lands in 1906 but an aren of 980 tedılans was let for winter crops and it is hoped to get in a considerable area under cotton this summer e It is in one of these government lands where good subsoil water is found close to the surface that it is hoped to form the dairy and cattle breeding farm, Lamaca District - Here we have bought six e properties of an approximate area of 3,270 n feudans costing a hout L.E.5 1/2 per feddan We to have had two 20 H P steam ploughs at work on s, these lands, an old line of wells and aqueduct e formerly existing on one of these properties has been opened up and is being repaired It is hoped that when it is in working or ler it will supply a constant supply of water sam mer and winter to one of our properties as it f|did when originally made. 8 Limassol. -We have bought here three pro. 1 | perties of an area of 1800 feddans approximately costing L.E. 6.6 each. On one of our properties here there is a supply of water from a stream throughout the year, mulberry and silkworm cultivation were carried on by a former owner and we are largely extending them. The subsoil water over some 400 feddans of these land is il close to the surface and of excellent quality we propose to start the silkworm culture here also A 12 H.P. stenm plough has just arrived tor f|these lands and one for the government lands in 1 the Famagusta and a second one is on the sea One of the principal products of Cyprus is the caro il bean; between two and three thons. and trees have been planted this year and it is proposed to plant them annually in large numbers. They only need summer wat. ering for the first 2 or 3 years and being 1 f deep-rooted they interfere little with the 1 cerial crops. Oranges and pomegranate plantations are also being laid down wherever Summer irrigation can be assured : on mnoh of our land good subsoil water exists which can be raised by means of sakkich, and windmills. The development of land by these means takes time. One may calculate that pomeyramates will hear after 3 or 4 years, oranges after five and enrouls after ten. Nearly all the land this year has been manured by chemical manure: chiefly mineral phosphate of which a large stock remains in hand. The difficulty in obtaining steam ploughs, owing to the large demand on the manufacturers bas prevented our getting as large an area under crops this winter as we should leave likely, and owing to the lateness of the antuan rains the sowing season was greatly curtailed. Until the survey of our lands is complete. ted it is difficult to state the exact area of the areas cultivated But in approximate figures we have the following winter crops.

Our share of these cultures is one halt, or two thirds of the total produce. There is also an area of about 127 fed, which has actually been sown since the end of 1906 in cereals and retches. Part of the expenses of these areas are included in 1906 accounts; remainder will come into the 1997 exploita. tion. We have also rented the lands bought from the government 980 fed. Before I finish I must say a few words as regards the market price of one shares to-day Many shareholders have asked the reason for their great discount which would argue a loss of over L.E. 100,000 If you look at our balance sheet you can see that we have incurred no losses nor made risky investments on which a loss could be incurred, we have on the contrary abstained from any affair in which it seemed we should incur an nndaly speculative risk. If any gentlemen present would like to ask any questions or mike any remarks we shall be glad to hear them.' Information as regards the retails of some items to the bala sheet was asked for by Sulaimon Bey Abunnd after this had been given he expressed an opinion that more information as to the work of the Company | should be made public from time to time. The chairman stated that a similar request had been made by other shareholders and that the Board would gladly accede to it. The chairman then moved the adoption of the Report and Balance sheet, as presented, for the period ending December 31st 1906. Captain R.C. Westropp seconded the motion which was carried unanimously. A The re-election of the auditors, Messrs. Russell Kerr and Wyatt, with a fee of L E. 150, having been proposed by the Chairman and seconded by Capt. Westropp was also carried unanimously.

div.head: TELEGRAMS
THE CAPITULATIONS
LORD CROMER'S PROPOSALS
THE "TIMES' APPROVES
div.p: LONDON, April 5. The Times" warmly supports Lord Cromer's proposal to reform the Capitulations under the safeguards indicated, on the ground that the Capitulations in the present form 1 become a formidable obstacle to good government and progress and an insuperable barrier to serious legislation which would benefit Europeans and natives alike. (Reuter)

div.head: ROOSEVELT AND TRUSTS
COMBINATIONS OF MAGNATES
div.p: LONDON, April 5. The Times" warmly supports Lord Cromer's proposal to reform the Capitulations under the safeguards indicated, on the ground that the Capitulations in the present form 1 become a formidable obstacle to good government and progress and an insuperable barrier to serious legislation which would benefit Europeans and natives alike. (Reuter)

div.head: AT ST. PETERSBURG
PREPARING FOR TROUBLE
div.p: PREPARING FOR TROUBLE. . ST PETERSBURG, April 5. Troops are pouring into the city similarly to the occasion of the dissolution of the first Dama. (Reuter) Sr. PETERSBURG, April 5. Cossacks and Dragoons have been quartered in the factory district of the city. The Guards have been ordered to hold themselves in readiness for eventualities, (Router)

div.head: THE DUTCH CABINET
RESIGNATION WITHDRAWN
div.p: THE HAGUE, April 5. At Queen Wilhelmina's request the Cabinet have withdrawn their resignation, except the War Minister, whose successor, M Van Rappart, however, holds his predecessor's views. The military policy of the country will thus be unchanged. (Reuter)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE
div.p: Rose, April 5. Italy considers that the submission to the Hague Conference of the proposal to limit Armaments is less likely to hurt the susceptibilities of certain powers than the Anglo-American proposal. (Reuter)

div.head: THAW DECLARED SANE
div.p: New York, April 5. The lunacy commission has decided that Thaw is sane.

div.head: THE MONTAGNINI CASE
div.p: i Paris, April 5. M. Lemarchand, Minister at Montevideo, who divulged the professional secret in favour of Mgr. Montagnini, will come before a council of discipline. (lacas )
